question: What keyword is used to declare an interface in Java?
Can an interface in Java contain method implementations?

options.a: Yes, they can contain full method implementations.
options.b: No, they cannot contain method implementations, only method signatures.
options.c: Yes, but only in Java 8 and later versions.
options.d: Yes, they can contain private method implementations.

question: Starting with which version of Java were default methods allowed in interfaces?
What types of method implementations were added to interfaces in Java 9?
What happens if a class implements an interface but does not implement all of its non-default methods?

options.a: The class is automatically marked as abstract.
options.b: The class is considered to not properly implement the interface.
options.c: The class is allowed to provide its own implementations for the missing methods.
options.d: The class must extend another class to implement the missing methods.

question: Which is the root class in the Java type system that all classes must extend?
How many types can a Java interface have as of the current version mentioned in the context?
Can a Java interface be instantiated directly?

options.a: Yes, interfaces can be instantiated just like classes.
options.b: No, interfaces cannot be instantiated and must be implemented by a class.
options.c: Yes, but only through anonymous classes.
options.d: No, but it can be used as a type for object references.

question: What is the main benefit of using interfaces in Java?

options.a: They provide a mechanism for multiple inheritance.
options.b: They allow for the creation of anonymous classes.
options.d: They facilitate the implementation of the singleton pattern.

question: What must a class that implements an interface do?

options.a: Implement all default methods described in the interface.
options.b: Implement all abstract methods described in the interface, or be abstract itself.
options.c: Override every interface method with a lambda expression.
options.d: Provide an implementation for only the static methods of the interface.
